docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers have found that the best predictor of youths' being at a healthy weight is having two parents who are of normal weight. For those teenagers who did have an obese parent, the best protective factor against being overweight was eating breakfast every day. The report appears in the January issue of The Journal of the American Dietetic Association.

headline.main: Overweight Children Linked to Overweight Parents

docs.abstract: Heather Fiore, Strong Children's Diabetes Center clinical nutrition specialist, conducts study that shows strongest indicator of childhood obesity is having two overweight parents; research, which is published in Journal of the American Dietetic Assn, also finds best protective measure is giving children breakfast; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Researchers have found that the best predictor of youths' being at a healthy weight is having two parents who are of normal weight. For those teenagers who did have an obese parent, the best protective factor against being overweight was eating...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN DIETETIC ASSN

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical problems at birth increase the risk of anorexia and bulimia later, a new study reports. Babies' early eating difficulties, poor muscle tone, low birth weight and a placenta with defective blood circulation were all associated with eating disorders by the time the children were 16 to 18 years old.

headline.main: Early Health Problems Predict Later Eating Woes

docs.abstract: Dr Paolo Santonastaso, University of Padua psychiatry professor, leads study on link between medical problems at birth and development of eating disorder in teenagers; research, which is published in Archives of General Psychiatry, identifies variety of causative factors, but points out that many children born with medical issues do not develop eating disorders; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Medical problems at birth increase the risk of anorexia and bulimia later, a new study reports.     Babies' early eating difficulties, poor muscle tone, low birth weight and a placenta with defective blood circulation were all associated with eating...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Tall people live longer than short people. THE FACTS -- Everyone knows that being tall has its benefits. Greater social and economic prospects are two of the more obvious ones, studies suggest. But can a taller stature also mean a longer life? The answer: It's debatable. Scientists have known for years, for example, that as the standard of living in a society improves, giving people greater access to nutrition, the average height and life span tend to go up. Widespread malnutrition and hardships, on the other hand, usually have the opposite effect.
docs.abstract: There is no evidence that person's height impacts their longevity; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: THE CLAIM -- Tall people live longer than short people.    THE FACTS -- Everyone knows that being tall has its benefits. Greater social and economic prospects are two of the more obvious ones, studies suggest. But can a taller stature also mean a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Lapiana had an ominous family history: both his parents had Type 2 diabetes, and both died of heart disease -- the most frequent cause of death in all forms of diabetes. Since his 20's, Mr. Lapiana has had hypertension, a danger signal for diabetes and for heart disease. But until he was 50, when he mentioned his unquenchable thirst -- a symptom of diabetes -- to a doctor, Mr. Lapiana had slipped under the medical radar. The doctor tested his blood sugar and found that his glucose was five times as high as the normal level.
docs.abstract: Evidence continues to mount supporting link between diabetes and heart disease; recent study published in New England Journal of Medicine holds that aggressively lowering person's blood sugar level can cut risk of heart attack and stroke almost in half; research shows that heart disease may precede symptoms of diabetes and experts agree that either condition should signal doctors to look for and treat other condition as well; treatment options discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors now have solid evidence that aggressively lowering a person's blood sugar level can cut the risk of heart attack and stroke nearly in half.

docs.lead_paragraph: The more teeth people have lost, the greater their risk of cardiovascular problems, a new study suggests. Researchers analyzed data from a nationwide telephone survey of health risk factors conducted by state health agencies with the help of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline.main: Brush and Floss (to Save Your Heart, of Course)

docs.abstract: Dr Paul I Eke, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention epidemiologist, leads study that finds tooth loss is linked to increased risk of cardiovascular problems; research is published in American Journal of Preventive Medicine; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: The more teeth people have lost, the greater their risk of cardiovascular problems, a new study suggests.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: I eagerly anticipated the Labor Day weekend last year. As a work-at-home mother with a toddler and a newborn, the idea of a long weekend rendered me giddy. I was looking forward to a few days with nothing more ambitious planned than some walks around the block. Instead, I spent the weekend in an intensive care unit where my husband, Nathan, was in an induced coma.

headline.main: Bacteria Grab A Windpipe And Hold It Hostage

docs.abstract: Jordana Horn Marinoff Cases column describes her husband Nathan's fight against severe epiglottitis; his treatment required two-day-long induced coma; condition is most common in children from 2 to 6 (M)
docs.snippet: At first, it seemed like a cold. But this bug had a killer instinct.

docs.lead_paragraph: In one room, a woman sobs into her hands after learning that her breast cancer has spread to her liver. Next door, a young man cured of lymphoma two years ago listens impassively to the news that his disease is back. Down the hall, a grizzled middle-aged hardware store owner hears that despite radiation treatment his prostate cancer is now in his bones. ''You sure of that?'' he says incredulously to the young doctor breaking the news. ''You sure those were my films?''

headline.main: Doctors Learn How to Say What No One Wants to Hear

docs.abstract: National Cancer Institute-backed program to help train oncologists on ways to tell patients bad news about their condition described; Dr Anthony Back, Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center oncologist who was one of founders of program and is one of its teachers, holds that training will improve communication skills and care; program uses actors to portray cancer patients going through various stages of illness; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Cancer doctors can now take a short immersion course to learn how to do the hardest part of their job: doling out bad news.

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients with debilitating pain from chronic illness, accidents, surgery or advanced cancer have long had problems getting adequate medication to control their pain and make life worth living. Now the federal government, and especially the Drug Enforcement Administration, is working overtime to make it even harder for doctors to manage serious pain, including that of dying patients trying to exit this world gracefully.

headline.main: Let's Get Serious About Relieving Chronic Pain Stuart Bradford

docs.snippet: Patients with debilitating pain from chronic illness, accidents, surgery or advanced cancer have long had problems getting adequate medication to control their pain and make life worth living.      Now the federal government, and especially the Drug...

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients with debilitating pain from chronic illness, accidents, surgery or advanced cancer have long had problems getting adequate medication to control their pain and make life worth living.

headline.main: Let's Get Serious About Relieving Chronic Pain

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses management of chronic pain and reluctance of many physicians to prescribe potentially addictive pain relievers for fear of prosecution by Drug Enforcement Administration agents; New England Journal of Medicine article by palliative care Drs Timothy E Quill and Diane E Meier says patient worries about undertreatment of pain is justified; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The federal government is working overtime to make it even harder for doctors to manage serious pain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Men who have been screened for prostate cancer by the most commonly used tests have no greater chance of surviving the disease than those who have not been screened at all, new research has found. A report on the research, published yesterday in The Archives of Internal Medicine, found that neither a prostate specific antigen test, known as a P.S.A., nor a rectal examination worked to reduce deaths from prostate cancer.

headline.main: Report Casts Fresh Doubts On Prostate Cancer Testing

docs.abstract: Dr John Concato of Veterans Affairs Connecticut Healthcare System leads study that shows men who have been screened for prostate cancer have no greater chance of surviving illness than those men who were not screened; research, which is published in Archives of Internal Medicine, suggests that doctors present all options to patients considering screening (M)
docs.snippet: Neither of the most commonly used tests to screen for prostate cancer worked to reduce deaths from the disease, a new study suggests.
